message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and playing badminton suggest Tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Option A is incorrect because excessive stress to bone is associated with stress fractures. Option B refers to Olecranon bursitis, which presents with swelling and pain on the tip of the elbow. Option D refers to Golfer’s elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist flexion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history of playing badminton recreationally and tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus suggest lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow. This is caused by repeated wrist extension. Excessive stress to bone may cause stress fractures, bursal inflammation may cause olecranon bursitis, and repeated wrist flexion may cause medial epicondylitis or golfer’s elbow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and the activity of playing badminton suggest that the most likely cause is lateral epicondylitis, or tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Excessive stress to bone would result in a stress fracture, bursal inflammation would cause pain around the olecranon bursa, and repeated wrist flexion would cause medial epicondylitis or golfer's elbow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and the activity of playing badminton suggest that the most likely cause is repeated wrist extension, which can cause lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow. Excessive stress to bone will cause stress fractures, while bursal inflammation will cause olecranon bursitis. Repeated wrist flexion will cause medial epicondylitis or golfer's elbow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Playing badminton involves repeated wrist extension, which can cause lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow). Tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus and pain reproduced by supinating the forearm against resistance further support this diagnosis. Excessive stress to bone (option A) would suggest a stress fracture, which is less likely given the history and examination findings. Bursal inflammation (option B) may cause pain and swelling but is less likely to be the underlying cause in this case. Repeated wrist flexion (option D) is not typically associated with lateral epicondylitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and the activities of the patient suggest the most likely underlying cause is repeated wrist extension, which can lead to lateral epicondylitis (also known as tennis elbow). Excessive stress to bone would cause a stress fracture, bursal inflammation would cause olecranon bursitis, and repeated wrist flexion would cause medial epicondylitis (also known as golfer's elbow).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Excessive stress to bone could lead to stress fractures, but would not present with tenderness over the lateral surface of the left distal humerus. Bursal inflammation would present with swelling and warmth over the affected area, which is not mentioned in the scenario. Repeated wrist flexion would not cause pain on the outer side of the left elbow.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and playing badminton suggest lateral epicondylitis, also known as tennis elbow, which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Options A and B are unlikely causes of this condition, and option D is the opposite motion of the affected area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s pain on the outer side of the elbow, especially when supinating the forearm against resistance, suggests lateral epicondylitis or “tennis elbow,” which is caused by repeated wrist extension. Excessive stress to bone, bursal inflammation, and repeated wrist flexion are not associated with this specific condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has pain on the outer side of her left elbow, which is characteristic of tennis elbow or lateral epicondylitis. This condition is caused by repeated wrist extension, as commonly seen in sports such as badminton. Excessive stress to bone would cause fractures or stress fractures, bursal inflammation would cause pain and swelling in the bursa, and repeated wrist flexion would cause tendinitis in the flexor tendons of the forearm.
